awd_titl_txt: MechBio 2018: The Mechanome in Action; Irvine, California; July 26-27, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
The emerging field of mechanobiology requires the coordination of knowledge from biologists, physicists, engineers and chemists. There are substantial barriers for interaction between these fields due to methodological and cultural differences. Thus, there is a critical need for developing collaborations between the fields, without which we will be unable to comprehend the mechanical basis of fundamental biological processes. The broad goal of this workshop is to establish mechanobiology as an interdisciplinary and collaborative field, much as the field of systems biology has been established in recent decades. This workshop, "Mechbio symposium: The Mechanome in Action", will bring together researchers from multiple disciplines in July of 2018 at the University of California, Irvine, to discuss recent advances in research that addresses how mechanical signals are read, generated, and transmitted by living systems.

The workshop will impact the training of future leaders in mechanobiology. The eve of the workshop will feature a graduate student symposium that will be chaired by two graduate student co-organizers under the advisement of the Organizers. This will be an opportunity for a new generation to express their own interests and priorities, delegate responsibilities, and organize a scientific event. It will also serve the larger goal of the workshop by generating interactions between trainees across laboratories.  We will offer Mechbio Opportunity Awards for new collaborations that are established during the course of the meeting. This award will be open to attendees and will provide reciprocal travel between the labs of new collaborators. Awardees will be required to present their findings at a future meeting. This type of award has been highly successful at the UC Irvine Center for Complex Biological Systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

The project, funded under NSF Award #1832921, aimed to advance the interdisciplinary field of mechanobiology by organizing meetings that focused on how mechanical signals are read, generated, and transmitted in living systems. Over the course of the project, we organized symposia, workshops, and seminars that brought together biologists, physicists, engineers, chemists, mathematicians, and computational scientists to foster collaboration, disseminate knowledge, and encourage innovative research. Specifically, our symposia provided (1) an environment for presenting cutting-edge research in mechanobiology, (2) interdisciplinary connections that highlight similarity in goals even through differences in approaches, and (3) new collaboration, especially including graduate students.

Intellectual Merit

Our efforts focused on enhancing interdisciplinary communication and collaboration in mechanobiology. Key outcomes included:

  • Symposia and Workshops: Events in 2018 and 2019 provided platforms for ~250 participants each, with sessions covering topics such as tissue engineering, cancer mechanobiology, and ion channel mechanotransduction. These gatherings encouraged interdisciplinary dialogue, leading to new collaborations and research opportunities. Feedback from symposia attendees was overwhelmingly positive, with participants praising the structure, the quality of presentations, and networking opportunities that facilitated meaningful cross-disciplinary exchanges.

  • Opportunity Awards: Two cross-institutional projects emerged from the 2018 symposium. One project developed robust interfaces between cells and sensor surfaces, with findings contributing to cell electrophysiology advancements. The second project investigated photoswitchable lipids for studying mechanically activated ion channels.

  • Seminar Series: Despite disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, virtual and in-person seminars by leading scientists, including Dr. Zheng Shi and Dr. Daniel Goldman, engaged diverse audiences and sparked meaningful scientific discussions. In total, these events reached approximately 100 participants, including students, postdoctoral researchers, and faculty members.

Broader Impacts

This project significantly contributed to the development of human resources and community building within mechanobiology:

  • Training and Professional Development: Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows gained valuable experience through seminars, poster presentations, and collaborative projects. Opportunities for networking with leading scientists and peers facilitated career development and skill enhancement.

  • Diversity and Inclusion: Efforts were made to highlight the work of women and underrepresented groups in STEM. Approximately 50% of speakers at key events were women, and the symposia welcomed students and researchers from a variety of academic and cultural backgrounds, creating an inclusive environment for interdisciplinary exchange.

  • Public Dissemination: The project’s findings and resources were widely shared through conference websites and social media channels, such as Twitter, broadening access to the broader scientific community. Feedback indicated that attendees valued these resources for learning about the latest advances and staying connected with the field of mechanobiology.

  • Fostering Interdisciplinary Awareness and Collaboration Across Scientific Communities: The participants were roughly split equally in thirds between departments of engineering, biology or medicine, and physics or mathematics. One of the largest impacts we have discovered is the awareness of what is happening in communities that pursue similar scientific questions but do not normally interact.

  • Impact on the development of human resources: The conference provided an educational opportunity for undergrad students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows to learn about the upcoming and increasingly important area of Mechanobiology. Principal investigators, faculty members, and staff scientists from different fields were able to attend talks from different areas and initiate collaborative interactions based on the discussions at the conference.

Challenges and Adaptations

Pandemic-related disruptions necessitated significant adjustments in later years, including transitioning to virtual formats. While virtual events proved less effective for fostering scientific interactions, they helped promote early-career researcher participation and collaboration, and provided essential continuity during challenging times, serving as a bridge to the 2024 MechBio Symposium in Colorado.

Future Directions

Building on the foundation established during this project, future efforts will aim to sustain the momentum of interdisciplinary mechanobiology research through continued symposia, collaborative opportunities, and dissemination of findings. By prioritizing the participation of emerging scientists, the project ensures a vibrant and dynamic future for the field.

This project has advanced both the intellectual and broader impacts of mechanobiology, fostering a collaborative and inclusive scientific community while addressing critical questions about the mechanics of life.
